channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Avalanche in French Alps Kills 4 Snowboarders
item.media:description: Rescue crews searching for victims of an avalanche near the French ski resort of Tignes on Monday.
item.media:credit: Sylvain Muscio/Le Dauphine, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The snowboarders, including an instructor, were off-piste and were preparing to descend a steep slope at the Tignes ski resort in the Vanoise range.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: St. Petersburg Journal: Fight Over Control of a Cathedral Shows St. Petersburg’s Contrarian Side
item.media:description: An artist passing St. Isaac’s Cathedral in St. Petersburg, Russia, in late January. The cathedral is managed by a museum set up by the Soviets in 1928.
item.description: A plan to transfer St. Isaac’s from a museum’s oversight to the Russian Orthodox Church, a political force elsewhere in Russia, has drawn protests.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Steps Into France’s Political Void
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, a candidate for the French presidency, last week at a campaign stop in Montlouis-sur-Loire, near Tours.
item.description: The French former economy minister claims to transcend parties, but by not defining himself, he risks being seen as a candidate who stands for nothing.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Hamas Appoints Hard-Line Militant as Gaza Leader
item.media:description: The Hamas leaders Ismail Haniya, left, and Moussa Abu Marzouk in 2014. Mr. Haniya is now contending for the top post in Hamas’s political bureau abroad.
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.description: The election of Yehya Sinwar could further isolate the Palestinian coastal enclave and portend a more aggressive stance against Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Ahmadreza Djalali, Iranian Scientist, May Face Death Penalty, Family Says
item.media:description: Ahmadreza Djalali, who specializes in disaster medicine, in a photo from Facebook.
item.description: European officials have protested the detention of Dr. Djalali, a Swedish citizen who was said to have been arrested in Iran in April.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Syria Used Chlorine Bombs Systematically in Aleppo, Report Says
item.media:description: A child being treated for respiratory distress in Aleppo, Syria, in December. Syrian forces used chlorine gas in the city at least eight times from Nov. 17 to Dec. 13, Human Rights Watch reported.
item.description: Human Rights Watch said Syrian forces dropped chlorine gas in areas where they planned to advance as part of a coordinated campaign to retake the city.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: As Japan Ages, Menus Adapt to Finding the Gourmet in Purées
item.media:description: Nursing home residents being helped while dining at the Chinese restaurant Kaze no Oto in a suburb of Yokohama, Japan. It is one of several restaurants that caters to that country’s aging population.
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.description: The country is a global leader in the kinds of societal changes needed for an aging society, including when it comes to “one of the greatest joys” — eating.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Employees of Missing Hong Kong Billionaire Are Barred From Leaving China
item.media:description: The offices of Tomorrow Group, the conglomerate controlled by Xiao Jianhua, in Beijing.
item.description: At least 30 people employed by Xiao Jianhua, who is believed to have been taken to mainland China, have come under one of the widest crackdowns on a private conglomerate in decades.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Migrating North, but to Mexico, Not the U.S.
item.media:description: Migrants waiting for food at the Community Center for Migrant Assistance in Caborca, Mexico. Last year, more than 8,100 foreigners applied for asylum in Mexico, nearly three times as many as in 2015.
item.description: A growing number of Latin American migrants are choosing to put down roots in Mexico rather than use it as a thruway to the United States.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Trump Speaks With Nigeria’s President, Who Hasn’t Been Seen in Weeks
item.media:description: Muhammadu Buhari, the president of Nigeria, center, was welcomed as he arrived in Gambia last month.
item.description: Nigeria’s president, Muhammadu Buhari, was receiving medical treatment in London, but his aides have disclosed few details.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 13 at Protest in Pakistan
item.media:description: Injured people were rushed to ambulances after a deadly bombing in Lahore, Pakistan, on Monday.
item.description: About 400 pharmacists had gathered in front of an assembly building in Lahore to protest a new law when the attacker detonated his explosives.
item.dc:creator: DANIYAL HASSAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Mob Kills Eloped Lovers After Storming Afghan Police Station
item.description: Fleeing an arranged marriage, the couple were shot to death by family members in what is often called an honor killing. There have been no arrests.
item.dc:creator: ZAHRA NADER and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Justin Trudeau and Donald Trump Try to Bridge Some Gaps While Avoiding Others
item.description: President Trump wants to renegotiate NAFTA, a free-trade pact that Canada depends on.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Race to Document Rare Plants Before These Cliffs Are Ground to Dust
item.media:description: A small lake has formed at the bottom of one of the Kampot karsts in Phnom Kampong Trach, a mountain in Cambodia.
item.media:credit: Omar Havana for The New York Times
item.description: The species native to Cambodia’s limestone karsts exist nowhere else. Now these unique environments are being pulverized for cement.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Election in Indonesia’s Capital Could Test Ethnic and Religious Tolerance
item.media:description: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the governor of Jakarta, Indonesia’s capital. While campaigning ahead of elections on Wednesday, Mr. Basuki, who is ethnic Chinese and a Christian, has also been defending himself in court against charges of blasphemy against Islam.
item.description: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the Christian governor of Jakarta, is battling in the court of public opinion as well as the court of law, where he is accused of blasphemy against Islam.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Relief in Japan After Shinzo Abe’s Visit With Trump
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minster Shinzo Abe of Japan at the White House on Friday. A poll taken in Japan after the meeting found wide satisfaction with the talks.
item.description: President Trump, who frequently criticized Japan during the election campaign, offered assurances that Washington was committed to the country’s security.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: ISIS Fighter’s Australian Citizenship Is Revoked Under Antiterror Laws
item.media:description: Mark Dreyfus, Australia’s shadow attorney general from the opposition Labor Party, said the antiterrorism citizenship law sought to strike the right balance between security and citizens’ rights.
item.description: An Islamic State fighter who posted a photo of a beheaded Syrian online is the first dual national to be stripped of citizenship under the laws, news reports said.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: North Korea Claims Progress on Long-Range Goal With Missile Test
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, in an undated photo. Military experts in the region say that the country is still years away from achieving capabilities that it has claimed, like striking the continental United States, as well as its military bases in the Pacific.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The intermediate-range test is an important stride for the North as it pursues an ability to hit the United States with an intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Anger and Mistrust Fuel Unabated Protests in Romania
item.media:description: Thousands of people protested outside the main government building in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday, a week after the government reversed its decision to weaken a corruption law.
item.description: The unrest has continued even after the new government repealed a law that decriminalized some low-level corruption offenses.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Head of Spain’s Far-Left Party Survives Leadership Challenge
item.media:description: Pablo Iglesias, the head of Spain’s far-left Podemos Party, on Sunday after winning a vote challenging his leadership of the party.
item.description: The victory by Pablo Iglesias, head of the Podemos Party, gave him a strong mandate to stick with his anti-establishment line.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Switzerland Votes to Ease Citizenship for Third-Generation Immigrants
item.media:description: A poster in Zurich opposing the citizenship measure was graffitied over to read “Unchecked incitement? No — Yes to an easier path to citizenship,” instead of the original “Unchecked naturalization? No to an easier path to citizenship.”
item.description: Over 60 percent of voters approved a measure to simplify the citizenship process for foreigners under 25 whose parents and grandparents have permanent residence status.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: United Nations Memo: World’s Diplomats, Seeking a Bridge to Trump, Look to Haley
item.media:description: Nikki R. Haley, the new United States ambassador to the United Nations, with Secretary General António Guterres, left, in New York last month.
item.description: The diplomatic corps is lining up to meet Nikki R. Haley, the new ambassador to the United Nations, though her influence on President Trump remains unknown.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Netanyahu’s Meeting With Trump to Set Tone for U.S.-Israel Relations
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that he and President Trump “have known each other for years.”
item.description: The two leaders will talk face to face on Wednesday, opening a new chapter in the countries’ relationship, which was notably frosty under President Barack Obama.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: Memo From Berlin: Angela Merkel, Squeezed by Far Right, Now Faces a Rising Left
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel and Horst Seehofer, head of the center-right Christian Social Union party, in Berlin on Sunday. She is seeking a fourth four-year term as chancellor.
item.description: The German chancellor is seen as a critical leader in Europe. But with national elections this year, the question is whether voters will back her for a fourth term.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Top Opposition Leader in Cambodia Resigns as Election Nears
item.media:description: Sam Rainsy, until Saturday the leader of the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party, arriving in Phnom Penh, the capital, in August 2015. He fled the country that November to avoid jail time.
item.description: The move by Sam Rainsy came after the government began a series of actions that would allow it to dissolve the party he led.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Canada’s Conservatives Seek a Champion, and Redemption
item.media:description: Stephen Harper, then Canada’s prime minister, campaigning in Abbotsford, British Columbia, in October 2015, before Justin Trudeau unseated him.
item.description: Fourteen candidates are vying for the party leadership and aiming ultimately to unseat Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Here are four top contenders.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World War II Bomb Removal in Greece Forces 72,000 From Homes
item.media:description: A military truck carried an unexploded World War II bomb that had been defused by Greek army personnel on Sunday in Thessaloniki.
item.description: In the country’s biggest peacetime evacuation ever, residents of Thessaloniki left their homes as experts defused a bomb from below a gas station.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: After Gun Battle in Kashmir, Protests Turn Violent
item.media:description: Indian security forces near the site of a gun battle in Kashmir on Sunday.
item.description: Indian security forces fought militants for 12 hours, resulting in the deaths of four militants, two soldiers and one civilian. Another civilian died after a protest.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Jesus Can Teach Today’s Muslims
item.description: Don’t imitate the West and don’t retreat into rigid fundamentalism.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Opinion: What We’re Fighting For
item.media:description: United States Army soldiers transported Iraqi detainees captured during Operation Steel Curtain in 2005.
item.description: Our acts of moral courage defend America as surely as any act of violence.
item.dc:creator: PHIL KLAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: France, Without a Struggle, Is at a Loss
item.media:description: In Chartres, France, people holding blackboards showing the most important election issues for them, including health, peace, education and unity.
item.description: The country is now bereft of the two conflicts that long defined its politics: the Cold War and the workers’ movement.
item.dc:creator: MICHEL WIEVIORKA
